courseTitle: Introduction to World Literatures and Cultures
courseDescription: This multicultural course introduces the student to the forms and meanings of cultural expressions from around the world, with an emphasis on world literature. It provides students with the skills necessary for the appreciation and comparative analysis of these works as representations of rich and diverse cultural values. A primary focus of the course will be the role of culture in the formation of national and individual identity, paying special attention to gender, sexuality, race, class, and struggles for social justice. All works will be read in English.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical thinking regarding issues of gender, sexuality, race, class, and social justice

courseTitle: Honors: Introduction to World Literatures and Cultures
courseDescription: This multicultural course introduces the student to the forms and meanings of cultural expressions from around the world, with an emphasis on world literature. It provides students with the skills necessary for the appreciation and comparative analysis of these works as representations of rich and diverse cultural values. A primary focus of the course will be the role of culture in the formation of national and individual identity, paying special attention to gender, sexuality, race, class, and struggles for social justice. All works will be read in English. This course is reserved for students enrolled in the Honors College.
Technical and Digital Skills: Appreciation of different forms of cultural expression
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Understanding and respecting diverse cultural values
Engaging with complex issues around identity formation
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of cultural influence on national and individual identity

courseDescription: A study of selected topics for elective credit. These courses will appear in the course schedule.

This course provides students with an historic overview of films from a variety of European countries. Students will gain the vocabulary necessary to analyze individual films and for the comparative analysis of films from different cultural and historical contexts. The course will focus on issues such as national and individual identity, film as aesthetic form, gender and sexuality, and popular culture. (cross-listed with COMM 307)
Technical and Digital Skills: Comparative analysis of films from different cultural and historical contexts
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Developing and expressing informed opinions on films
Communicating film analysis in verbal and written forms
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Understanding and interpreting cultural and historical contexts
Critical thinking about national and individual identity, aesthetic form, gender, sexuality, and popular culture through film

courseDescription: Exploration of Japanese culture and society from local and global perspectives. Topics may include language, arts, literature, music, food, traditional and contemporary culture, entertainment, media, religion, gender, education and work. The course aims to foster in-depth cultural understanding beyond stereotypes and to develop critical thinking and analytical skills to reflect on one's own experiences and assumptions about cultural similarities and differences. All readings, discussions, and lectures in English. No knowledge of Japanese is necessary. Cross-listed with JAPN 310.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Reflective thinking on personal experiences and assumptions

courseDescription: This course is primarily a 'hands on' communicative course to develop cultural competence (verbal communication). Task-oriented communication strategies in cross-cultural training will be practiced by presenting students with models who demonstrate appropriate cultural skills. The course will include cognitive learning with lectures from experts (invited speakers), analysis of critical incidents and assigned readings, and application of sophisticated concepts from the behavioral and social sciences. Students will practice these skills by giving presentations, enriching self-awareness with group discussions on prejudice, racism, values and customs, and participation in guided cultural encounters (such as field trip assignments that demand new behaviors). Students will participate in role-playing and in simulations of real-life demands in extended experimental encounters with another culture or complex approximations of another culture. Effectively, students will learn how to communicate and collaborate with other people and cultures in a global age.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Application of behavioral and social science concepts

courseDescription: This is an intensive writing course designed with writing assignments that examine various cultural contexts that enable students to understand cultural content, style, audience and organization. The main objective of the course is increased awareness of and sensitivity to appropriate word choice, and syntax in the targeted languages. Students will engage in writing for different cultural audiences and in varied contexts such as literary, artistic and media expressions around the world. Special emphasis is placed on the methodology of close reading as students hone the analytics skills and vocabulary necessary to interpret idioms, regionalism, cultural expressions and overall intercultural skills observed in various genres and cultures. Students will analyze compelling global issues and the diverse cultural perspectives that inform them.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Understanding and interpreting cultural expressions and idioms
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing global issues from diverse cultural perspectives

courseDescription: A study of film as a means of communication from an intercultural perspective. The course is designed to cultivate an ability to deal with film in a critical way, as well as broaden understanding of film and culture in a global context. A variety of cinematic traditions will be examined including film works from Europe, the Middle East, Asia, Africa, and North and South America.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of global film and culture

courseDescription: In this course, students learn to value diverse global perspectives, and to seek multiple approaches to defining and solving problems based on intercultural awareness. This course will focus on the ways that culture and language influence human behavior, and on the practical development of communicative strategies, from compelling writing to effective discussion and collaboration.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Understanding and valuing diverse global perspectives
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem definition and solution using multiple cultural perspectives
Analyzing the influence of culture and language on human behavior
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Adapting communication to diverse cultural contexts

courseDescription: Internships in private, public, non-profit and business organizations that deal with global communications and world cultures.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of public, private, non-profit and business organizations
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Navigating public, private, non-profit, and business environments

courseDescription: This course invites students to discover approaches to global problems and concerns through an analysis of cultural expressions from around the world.  Students will consider the ways in which literary and artistic expression (literature, film, visual art, music) draw from and impact broader social and political contexts.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of global problems through cultural contexts
Interpretation of literature, film, visual art, and music
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussion and debate of global issues

courseDescription: This course will examine selected cultural studies perspectives on mass communication. It will cover cultural studies philosophies, theories, and/or approaches to the study of cultural artifacts and practices that may include some of the following: postmodernism, deconstruction, feminism, and post-colonialism. The readings will include theoretical texts as well as artistic or cultural texts that will more clearly illustrate the theoretical positions.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding and application of cultural studies theories
Interpretation of artistic and cultural texts
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communication of theoretical and philosophical ideas
Understanding and discussing postmodernism, deconstruction, feminism, and post-colonialism
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of cultural studies philosophies
Analysis and interpretation of cultural practices
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading discussions on cultural studies perspectives
Coordinating and synthesizing multiple theoretical positions

courseDescription: A study of communication styles and strategies around the world. Students will analyze how global concerns and national priorities are articulated across cultures and languages, and they will navigate techniques necessary for effective communication within intercultural contexts. This course, through interactive lectures, discussions, guest speaker presentations and case studies, is intended to prepare students to be fluent in intercultural understanding and global collaboration and to apply these skills in professional settings.
Technical and Digital Skills: Analysis of global concerns and national priorities

courseDescription: This course explores the cultural movements that have characterized the German-French commonalities and differences from the early 1900s through the 1990s in cross-disciplinary discourses such as film, literature, art, politics, and economics.

courseTitle: The Question of Memory in World Cultures
courseDescription: This class explores how societies across the world choose to remember people and events through culture. Students will consider 'official' manifestations – government-sponsored or public memorials and art – as well as general and popular culture such as museums, literature, film, TV, music, etc. The class will interrogate not only what is chosen to be memorialized but how it is memorialized, and how public memory of events is shaped by such choices. Students will consider what decisions are made at the local and national level, how those decisions are made, and what consultations or processes are considered necessary or desirable when deciding public memorials and artwork.

The first half of the 20th century was the most creative and destructive period in German and European history. Its rich cultural achievements included Viennese psychoanalytical theory of the turn of the century, Art Nouveau, German Expressionism, and the avant garde aesthetics of the Weimar Republic. Conversely, World War I and II exposed the cultural agony and human depravity of modern civilization. This course will trace these various aspects and developments in a variety of exemplary genres. Readings and discussions in German. (Cross-listed with GER 445/GER 545 and COMM 444/COMM 544)
Technical and Digital Skills: Artistic appreciation of the avant garde aesthetics of the Weimar Republic
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing and interpreting German and European history
Understanding the cultural impact of World War I and II

courseDescription: A study of fictional and non-fictional works by Spanish, Spanish-American, and U.S. Latina writers from the 16th to the 20th century. The course analyzes gender identity and roles and the interaction of gender, race, and class in literary representations of courtship and marriage, spirituality, nationalism, colonialism, and multiculturalism.
Technical and Digital Skills: Research on historical and sociocultural contexts
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Written and verbal communication in Spanish
Articulating complex ideas about gender, race, and class
Critiquing and interpreting various forms of literature
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Understanding and analyzing historical and cultural contexts
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading and participating in intellectual discussions

courseDescription: A survey of seminal texts by German-Jewish philosophers and writers from the Enlightenment to the present day, including Marx, Kafka, Freud, Schnitzler and Arendt.
Interdisciplinary research and the preparation of a senior thesis in international studies. This is a writing intensive course.

courseTitle: Entrepreneurship in World Languages and Cultures
courseDescription: This course is designed to help students enhance their personal and professional development through innovation guided by faculty members and professionals. It offers students an opportunity to integrate disciplinary theory and knowledge related to world languages and cultures through developing a nonprofit program, product, business, or other initiative with other students.

This course invites students to discover approaches to global problems and concerns through an analysis of cultural expressions from around the world.  Students will consider the ways in which literary and artistic expression (literature, film, visual art, music) draw from and impact broader social and political contexts.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Oral and written communication about cultural expressions
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of global problems and concerns
Interpretation of social and political contexts

courseDescription: This course invites students to discover approaches to global problems and concerns through an analysis of cultural expressions from around the world.  Students will consider the ways in which literary and artistic expression (literature, film, visual art, music) draw from and impact broader social and political contexts.
Technical and Digital Skills: Analysis of literary and artistic expressions
Understanding of global cultural expressions through various mediums like literature, film, visual art, music
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Understanding and interpretation of social and political contexts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of global problems and concerns
Critical evaluation of cultural impact on social and political contexts

courseTitle: Tutorial Work in Special Topics in World Cultural Studies
courseDescription: Independent readings and study on a topic to be selected under direction of professor.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Development and refinement of research questions

courseTitle: Tutorial Work in Special Topics in World Cultural Studies
courseDescription: Independent readings and study on a topic to be selected under direction of professor.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical reading and comprehension of academic texts
Analytical thinking on world cultural topics

courseDescription: This course explores the cultural movements that have characterized German-French commonalities and differences from the early 1900s through the 1990s in cross-disciplinary discourses such as film, literature, art, politics, and economics.
Technical and Digital Skills: Use of digital archives for historical data
Analysis of films, literature, and art from historical perspective
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of political and economic discourses

courseTitle: The Question of Memory in World Cultures
courseDescription: This class explores how societies across the world choose to remember people and events through culture. Students will consider 'official' manifestations – government-sponsored or public memorials and art – as well as general and popular culture such as museums, literature, film, TV, music, etc. The class will interrogate not only what is chosen to be memorialized but how it is memorialized, and how public memory of events is shaped by such choices. Students will consider what decisions are made at the local and national level, how those decisions are made, and what consultations or processes are considered necessary or desirable when deciding public memorials and artwork.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication in public and cultural contexts
Interpreting and explaining public memorials and art
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the influence of cultural memorials on public memory
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding and interpreting organizational decisions in cultural contexts
Leading discussions and debates on public memory

courseDescription: The first half of the 20th century was the most creative and destructive period in German and European history. Its rich cultural achievements included Viennese psychoanalytical theory of the turn of the century, Art Nouveau, German Expressionism, and the avant garde aesthetics of the Weimar Republic. Conversely, World War I and II exposed the cultural agony and human depravity of modern civilization. This course will trace these various aspects and developments in a variety of exemplary genres. Readings and discussions in German. (Cross-listed with GER 445/GER 545 and COMM 444/COMM 544)
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of cultural and historical contexts
Analyzing and interpreting film and literature

Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of gender, race, and class in literature

Technical and Digital Skills: Use of digital resources and databases for historical and literary research
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical reading and interpretation of texts
